clinical_study.brief_title: Duration of Red Blood Cell Storage
clinical_study.official_title: Duration of Red Blood Cell Storage Prior to Transfusion and Non-Transferrin-Bound Iron

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: Recent studies suggest that older stored blood is associated with worse outcomes in certain hospitalized patients. Red cells may be stored in a refrigerator prior to transfusion for up to 42 days by current Food and Drug Administration (FDA) standards. Refrigerator storage of red cells is associated with a storage lesion and the survival of transfused red cells decreases with increasing storage time, thus older blood is associated with an increased delivery of hemoglobin-iron to certain parts of the body. The investigators have preliminary data in mice and humans suggesting that delivery of a significant iron load from aged red cells leads to the production of a potentially toxic form of circulating iron called non-transferrin-bound iron. This study will determine the minimal duration of red blood cell (RBC) storage that leads to increases in circulating non-transferrin-bound iron in healthy human volunteers post-transfusion. The results from this study will help guide national guidelines for appropriate duration of RBC storage prior to transfusion, which is currently 6 weeks by FDA criteria. The overall objective of this research is to improve the safety of refrigerated storage of red blood cells before transfusion.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Factorial Assignment, Masking: Open Label

intervention.intervention_name: Transfusion of blood randomized to 1 week of storage
intervention.description: A standard autologous leukoreduced packed red blood cell unit will be collected and stored in AS-3 solution in the Columbia University Medical Center blood bank.
intervention.arm_group_label: Transfusion of 1 week stored red cells
